Solomon Islands 
 
The  proposed  Economic  Recovery  Support  Program  (ERSP)  is  a 
program cluster of grants totaling $10.0 million for two subprograms. The 
ERSP  will  assist  in  adjusting  to  an  economic  and  fiscal  deterioration 
aggravated  by  the  global  economic  crisis.  The  program  will  support 
improved  fiscal  management  and  structural  measures  that  will  aid 
economic recovery. Budget support will help protect the delivery of basic 
services  to  the  vulnerable  and  be  complemented  by  actions  to  engage 
with key stakeholders.

2015 as natural forest resources approached exhaustion. Gross domestic

The  ESRP  builds  on  the  macroeconomic  assessment  prepared  by  the 
International Monetary Fund through its 2009 Article IV Consultation. The 
consultation  concluded  that  new  external  assistance  in  the  form  of 
budget  support  can  provide  a  cushion  for  undertaking  more  lasting 
fiscal  adjustment  and  improving  budget  execution.  The  International 
Monetary Fund estimated a budget financing gap for the medium term of 
$25 million per year (around 4% of gross domestic product). 
 
The  ERSP  has  four  output  areas:  (i)  improved  fiscal  management,  (ii) 
productivity enhancing structural initiatives, (iii) support for the vulnerable, 
and (iv) communication and ownership of policy actions. Subprograms 1 
and 2 support the same four output areas, and these will be progressed 
concurrently under each subprogram. 
 
Output  (i)  targets  fiscal  sustainability.  This  is  to  ensure  the  government 
has the financial capacity to provide the investment and services needed 
to  support  economic  growth  and  development  over  the  medium  term. 
Public  financial  management  is  also  to  be  improved  under  output  (i), 
lifting the standard of governance and addressing priority needs identified 
in a 2008 Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability assessment. 
 
Output  (ii)  will  implement  reform  measures  that  can  build  the  productive 
base of the economy. This will help lift economic growth and diversify the 
economy away from unsustainable logging and foreign aid. The areas of 
focus  are:  (i)  state-owned  enterprises,  so  as  to  improve  their  efficiency, 

 reduce their drain on the budget, and reduce crowding out of the private 
sector;  (ii)  deregulation  of  the  telecommunications  industry,  to  expand 
service  coverage,  raise  standards,  and  reduce  prices;  (iii)  the  business 
regulatory environment, so as to directly reduce costs of doing business 
in  Solomon  Islands;  and  (iv)  transport  infrastructure,  in  order  to  raise 
investment  levels  and  service  standards  in  infrastructure  and  thereby 
reduce transport costs for business while improving access to health and 
education facilities and to markets. 
 
Output  (iii)  is  to  help  protect  the  vulnerable  from  the  effects  of  the 
economic slowdown. Additional financial resources provided by ADB will 
reduce a budget financing gap, thereby helping to preserve the delivery of 
basic transport services, rural health services, and basic education. 
 
Output (iv) brings stakeholders into the adjustment process in support of 
continued country ownership of the program. Close attention will be paid 
under  output  (iv)  to  communicating  the  government’s  strategy  for 
lessening  the  impact  of  the  global  economic  crisis  and  bridging 
communication gaps between economic stakeholders. 
 
The  impact  of  the  ERSP  will  be  the  achievement  of  a  higher  and  more 
inclusive  path  of  economic  growth.  The  outcome  of  the  program  will  be 
initiation of economic recovery with extra protection for the vulnerable and 
the fiscal position.  
 
The  core  economic  working  group  process  established  by 
the 
government  has  been  critical  to  the  formulation  of  a  single  government-
led policy matrix supported by key development partners. 
 
Support  for  the  vulnerable  is  a  feature  of  the  program,  in  recognition  of 
the extra hardship imposed by the global economic crisis and a preceding 
episode  of  high  inflation.  This  support  will  help  preserve  the  delivery  of 
essential  services  to  the  most  vulnerable.  It  is  also  proposed  the  ERSP 
will link to a Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction grant for social protection 
that  will  support  the  piloting  of  social  safety  nets  and  associated  policy 
development. 
 
The  program  cluster  period  will  be  from  1  March  2009  to  28  February 
2012.  A  single  tranche  grant  of  $5.0  million  is  to  be  disbursed  under 
subprogram  1  when  the  government  has  met  the  conditions  for 
effectiveness. For subprogram 2, a single tranche grant of $5.0 million will 
be  presented  for  consideration  and  approval  by  the  ADB  Board  of 
Directors based on the progress achieved in implementing subprogram 1, 
including  the  status  of  compliance  with  the  proposed  policy  actions  and 
the  readiness  of  the  government  to  undertake  the  succeeding  policy 
reform  measures.  Subprogram  2  is  expected  to  be  considered  by  the 
Board about 12 months after subprogram 1 grant effectiveness. 
 
ADB will provide a cluster of grants totaling $10.0 million, comprising two 
subprograms of $5.0 million each, from ADB’s Asian Development Fund 
on terms and conditions set forth in the draft grant agreement.

The  program  will  provide  broadly  distributed  benefits  by  helping  lessen

Key  risks  are  that  (i)  political  instability  weakens  fiscal  discipline  and 
policy  commitment,  particularly  in  the  lead-up  to  the  2010  election;  (ii) 
there is insufficient capacity in government to implement the program; (iii) 
the revenue position of the government deteriorates and impedes service 
delivery;  and  (iv)  excessive  growth  in  expenditure  crowds  out  essential 
expenditure,  making  it  difficult  to  achieve  and  capitalize  on  the  policy 
actions linked to the program. 
 
Program design mitigates these risks. The extension of the ERSP beyond 
the  2010  general  election  will  provide  the  flexibility  to  align  the  program 
with  the  commitment  and  policy  agenda  of  any  new  government.  The 
communications  and  engagement  strategy  will  build  community 
awareness  and  demand  for  the  program.  Technical  assistance  will  be 
provided  on  a  selective  basis  to  supplement  the  expertise  needed  to 
implement key policy actions. The risk of fiscal slippage will be lessened 
through  an  explicit  focus  in  the  ERSP  on  fiscal  discipline  and  the 
provision of technical assistance on economic and fiscal management. 
 
The ERSP also relies on (i) an improvement in the global economy; (ii) a 
positive response by the private sector to improved economic conditions; 
(iii) a commitment of government agencies to improved performance; (iv) 
the  provision  of  complementary  financial  and  technical  resources  by 
the  continued  operation  of  key 
development  partners;  and 
coordinating  mechanisms,  notably  the  monthly  monetary  monitoring

A. 

Development Performance 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

2. 
Gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  per  capita  grew  slowly  over  Solomon  Islands’  first  two 
decades of independence (granted in 1978). The slow development progress reflected a failure 
to  ensure  adequate  infrastructure  development,  as  well  as  sound  economic  and  natural 
resource management and public administration (Appendixes 3, 4, and 5). An outbreak of civil 
unrest in 1999 evidenced the severity of the problems. Successive administrations had failed to 
provide  the  leadership  and  policies  to  address  the  underlying  causes  of  civil  conflict  (uneven 
regional  development,  uneven  distribution  of  public  resources,  land  issues,  and  a  rising  youth 
population with little education and poor job prospects) and then proved incapable of imposing 
law and order.1 The civil conflict lasted to 2003, resulting in hundreds of deaths and displacing 
over 20,000 people. Much of the post-independence income growth was lost (Figure 1).  

3. 
Military and police forces arrived in July 2003 with the Regional Assistance Mission to 
Solomon Islands (RAMSI).2 Civil order was quickly restored and has generally been maintained, 
except  for  mob  riots  in  Honiara  in  April  2006.  A  surge  in  foreign  aid  under  the  umbrella  of 
RAMSI  then  funded  large  increases  in  development  budget  spending  that  lifted  total 
government expenditure (Figure 2). This initiated a post-conflict recovery. As the stimulus from 
rising  aid  leveled  off,  forestry,  agriculture,  and  fishing  activity  expanded  and  kept  economic 
growth  at  relatively  high  levels  to  2008.  The  post-conflict  growth  surge  saw  a  recovery  in 
average incomes. 

4. 
RAMSI  has  also  been  instrumental  in  helping  begin  the  rebuilding  of  the  state. 
Government finances have been brought under better control through improved public financial 
management  practices.  Business  confidence,  especially  amongst  traders  and  retailers,  has 
improved  with  the  restoration  of  law  and  order.  The  task  of  rebuilding  the  machinery  of 
government  is  ongoing,  through  technical  assistance  (TA)  programs  for  strengthening 
Parliament,  key  watchdog  agencies  (such  as  the  Office  of  the  Auditor  General),  the  public 
service, and provincial governments.

The  post-conflict  growth  surge  has masked  deep  problems  in  the  economy,  which  has 
5. 
become  dependent  on  very  high  levels  of  foreign  aid  and  unsustainably  high  rates  of  logging. 
The  government  has  continued  to capture  too little of  the  resource  rent  from  logging,  even  as 
logging rates grew to five times the sustainable rate in 2007. It has been known for some time 
there  would  be  a  sharp  drop  in  logging,  probably  starting  around  2009,  and  natural  forest 
resources  are  expected  to  be  largely  exhausted  before  2015.  Logging  rates  could  have  been 
curbed to extend the life of natural forests, or the unsustainably high income could have been 
saved  to  smooth  the  inevitable  drop-off  in  logging  income.  Such  preventative  action  was  not 
taken, however. 

  

3

Political  instability  and  poor  accountability  and  transparency  in  government  remain, 
6. 
fuelled  by  weaknesses  in  the  institutional  environment.3  These  weaknesses  have  undermined 
the  effectiveness  of  government,  which  in  turn  has  slowed  economic  growth  and  continues  to 
severely restrain economic prospects. Solomon Islands is likely to remain a weakly performing 
country with a fragile state until such shortcomings are addressed. In response, the government 
has adopted a broad-ranging development strategy. This Medium Term Development Strategy 
(MTDS) 2008–2010 seeks to provide the missing foundations of growth and development.4 

Economic  growth  prospects  rest  on  the  private  sector  and  on  developments  in  mining, 
7. 
agriculture, fishing, and, to a lesser extent, tourism. Progress is being made toward reopening a 
large  gold  mine  closed  during  the  civil  unrest,  and  there  is  potential  over  the  longer  term  to 
develop large nickel deposits. While mining projects would boost GDP, the sector would employ 
few people and there would be long lags before government revenues rose as a result. The best 
prospects  for  creating  jobs  and  boosting  government  revenues  lie  in  large-scale  palm  oil 
developments,  in  fishing  (there  is  already  one  large  fish  cannery),  and  in  the  smallholder  tree 
crops  of  cocoa  and  copra.  The  supply  of  fruit  and  vegetables  to  the  urban  centers  as  a 
substitute for imports also offers good prospects, as does the fledgling tourism industry. 

8. 
A  number  of  recent  studies  have  examined  economic  growth  prospects  under  various 
scenarios  (Appendix  3).  The  studies  have  identified  the  potential  for  economic  growth  after 
logging, albeit at only low to moderate rates that would see at best slow growth in real GDP per 
capita  in  the  medium  term.  The  studies  have  also  highlighted  the  necessity  of  concerted 
government  action  to  realize  the  potential  growth  (notably  through  increased  investment  in 
infrastructure,  efforts  to  improve  the  enabling  environment  for  the  private  sector,  governance 
reform, and maintaining macroeconomic stability) and the downside risk of inaction. 

B. 

Impact of the Global Economic Crisis 

1. 

Macroeconomic Impact 

9. 
The Solomon Islands economy has been among the most affected in the Pacific by the 
global  economic  crisis.  The  global  economic  crisis  has  brought  forward  the  sharp  economic 
slowdown  that  was  expected  between  2009  and  2015  as  natural  forest  logging  comes  to  an 
end. GDP growth averaged 7.3% per annum in the 5 years to 2008. Preliminary estimates are 
of  little  or  no  overall  economic  growth  in  2009.  Economic  data  suggest  the  rural  economy 
contracted over 2009.5 

10. 
The  value  of  goods  and  services  exports  was  down  by  more  than  20%  over  the  first 
three quarters of 2009 compared to the same period of 2008. The drop was driven by decline in 
logging, copra, and fishing. Export volumes of these commodities were down by 29%, 46%, and 
23%, respectively, over the first three quarters of 2009 compared to the same period of 2008.

2. 

Fiscal Impact 

14. 
The real value of government tax revenue almost doubled over the 5 years to 2008, but 
a  revenue  shortfall  emerged  over  the  first  half  of  2009  as  the  economy  slowed  and continued 
through the remainder of the year. The 2009 budget had forecast domestically sourced revenue 
at SI$1,642 million for 2009, but actual collections were only SI$1,420 million. The weakening in 
revenue,  combined  with  a  government  commitment  to  not  borrow,  necessitated  widespread 
spending cuts. In April 2009, nonpayroll recurrent expenditure was cut by 10% and civil service 
hiring was frozen. A further temporary 25% cut (termed a reservation) was made on nonpayroll 
recurrent  expenditure,  to  be  reversed  in  the  December  quarter  if  funding  allowed  (the 
reservation  was  relaxed  in  late  October).  Large  cuts  were  also  made  to  domestically  financed 
development  outlays.  The  general  public  sector  wage  increase  for  2009  was  kept  to  4.5%, 
implying  a  reduction  in  real  terms  of  around  3.5%  over  the  year.  Offsetting  these  measures, 
however, were two supplementary appropriation bills which authorized a range of new spending 
measures  (totaling  3.7%  of  total  expenditure  and  1.7%  of  GDP).  Items  funded  under  the 
supplementary appropriations include a compensation payment for Solomon Telekom, disaster 
relief, election funding, scholarships, rural electrification, and minor building works. 

15.

below  the  level  needed  for  normal  operations.  Service  delivery  was  adversely  affected  and 
infrastructure investment and maintenance were underfunded.6 The latest information from the 
Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT) is that the fiscal situation remained tight in early 2010.

3. 

Poverty and Gender Impacts 

16. 
The economic slowdown is occurring in a context of rapid population growth, high levels 
of  urban  unemployment,  high  poverty  rates,  and  gender  imbalances  (Appendixes  6  and  7). 
Tighter  constraints  on  public  service  delivery  arising  from  the  revenue  deterioration  have  the 
potential to place extra pressure on the vulnerable, who have poor access to basic services and 
limited income-earning and employment opportunities. Approximately one-third of the population 
is  estimated  to  live  below  the  basic-needs  poverty  line.  Households  headed  by  women  are 
disproportionately  represented  among  those  living  in  poverty.  Many  households  also  live  just 
above the poverty line and can drop into poverty as conditions deteriorate. The vulnerable within 
the community are more exposed to the negative impacts of the economic slowdown and have 
fewer reserves with which to meet their needs. 

17.  Women  in  particular  are  likely  to  face  greater  impacts  from  the  economic  slowdown 
because  of  tighter  constraints  on  access  to  essential  public  services.  Gender  disparities  are 
significant  in  education,  as  girls  are  often  pulled  out  of  school  for  economic  reasons.  Fertility 
rates are high, and women’s access to health and family planning services are poor (especially 
in rural areas), as indicated by a high maternal mortality rate. Poor access to basic infrastructure 
(e.g.,  roads,  clean  water,  and  sanitation)  generates  additional  burden  on  women’s  lives  that 
limits  their  time  and  opportunity  for  productive  and  income-generating  activities.  Actions  to 
maintain access to the limited services that are available is central to limiting the adverse social 
impact of the economic slowdown.

18.

remain  below  trend  and  that  “large  and  potentially  destabilizing  macroeconomic  imbalances 
could emerge, necessitating sizable policy adjustment, as well as new exceptional financing.”7 
Modest  growth  is  expected  from  2010  to  2011,  before  a  projected  commencement  of  gold

balance of payments (Table 1).8 

The strain on the fiscal and current account positions that emerged in 2009 is projected 
19.

4% of GDP ($25 million) is projected for 2010 and 2011.9 An external financing gap on a similar

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

The  expected  impact  of  the  program  is  achievement  of  a  higher  and  more  inclusive 
22. 
economic growth path. The expected outcome is initiation of economic recovery while protecting 
the vulnerable and the fiscal position. The impact and outcome are to be achieved by helping 
initiate a transition away from dependence on foreign aid and unsustainable logging to private 
sector-led economic growth from the agriculture, fishing, tourism, and mining sectors.  

B. 

Policy Framework 

The  primary  contribution  of  the  ERSP  will  be  in  helping  address  the  underlying 
23. 
shortcomings  in  the  economic  growth  and  development  process.  Importantly,  actions  will  be 
undertaken to  strengthen  fiscal  management.  This  will  help  consolidate  the  fiscal  position  and 
improve the operation of government agencies so the government is better able to respond to 
the economic slowdown and fund priority investments and essential services over the medium 
term.  Structural  measures  will  improve  the  operation  of  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  and 
help  modernize  the  regulation  of  the  economy.  Extra  effort  will  be  taken  to  make  the  growth 
process  more  inclusive.  Notably,  the  ERSP  will  help  deliver  essential  services  by  partially 
meeting the government’s overall budget financing requirements. 

24. 
Consistent with the MTDS 2008–2010, the ERSP is oriented to achieving private sector-
led  economic  growth.12  The  environment  for  private  sector  development  is  to  be  supported  at 
both  macroeconomic  and  microeconomic  levels.  At  the  macro  level,  the  private  sector  will  be 
assisted  by  supporting  aggregate  demand  and  lessening  fiscal  stress.  At  the  micro  level,  the 
emphasis  will  be  on  helping  reform  of  SOEs  through  efforts  to  support  the  continued 
development  of  infrastructure  and  accumulation  of  human  capital  and  on  reducing  the  cost  of 
doing business by modernizing the legal framework for business. 

25. 
In preparing the program, priority has been given to country ownership and keeping the 
program  at  a  level  that  is  manageable  given  capacity  limitations.  This  is  to  help  ensure  the 
sustainability  of  outcomes.  The  formulation,  implementation,  and  monitoring  of  the  ERSP 
through  the  CEWG  process  is  key  to  achieving  sustainable  results.  The  program  is  also 
designed  to  implement  ADB’s  interim  country  partnership  strategy  for  Solomon  Islands,  which 
promotes  equitable  private  sector-led  economic  growth  through  improved  transportation 
infrastructure  and  services  and  a  stronger  business  enabling  environment.13  The  program 
directly addresses the guiding priority of ADB’s strategy of promoting good governance.

C. 

Policy Actions 

26. 
Potentially  high  return  and  feasible  areas  of  policy  action  have  been  identified.  These 
are feasible both in political terms and within the public sector’s implementation capacity when 
accompanied by targeted external assistance. The program has four output areas: (i) improved 
fiscal  management,  (ii)  productivity  enhancing  structural  initiatives,  (iii)  support  for  the 
vulnerable, and (iv) communication and ownership of policy actions. The policy actions will be 
pursued through two subprograms. Subprograms 1 and 2 support the same four output areas, 
which will be progressed concurrently under each subprogram.  

27. 
The  policy  actions  build  on  a  dialogue  between  the  government  and  ADB  and  key 
development partners over a number of years. It includes significant actions by the government 
that demonstrate a continuing commitment to improved economic and fiscal management. The 
policy  actions  provide  a  package  of  priority,  sequenced  reforms  in  areas  critical  to  achieving 
sustainable, inclusive economic growth. The intention is to continue improvement of economic 
and fiscal management through further action following completion of the ERSP.  

28. 
The ERSP’s policy actions are drawn from the policy matrix prepared through the CEWG 
process.14  The  link  to  the  government  policy  matrix  ensures  the  ERSP  is  aligned  with  the 
government’s own plans and is harmonized with support provided by key development partners. 
The ongoing dialogue of the CEWG is central to implementing and monitoring the ERSP and to 
sustaining the results achieved under the program.  

1. 

Output (i): Improved Fiscal Management 

29. 
The  output  is  directed  to  achieving  the  medium-term  goals  of  overall  fiscal  discipline, 
providing strategic guidance to PFM reform, ensuring effective expenditure controls are in use, 
raising the efficiency and fairness of the revenue system, and improving the allocation of public 
resources  through  strengthened  budgeting  and  planning  processes.  The  output  will  help 
achieve the short-term fiscal consolidation now urgently required while seeking to maintain the 
capacity to fund essential services and public investment over the medium term. The output will 
also help address shortcomings in governance. The emphasis is on initiatives that address the 
weakest  areas  of  PFM  identified  in  a  2008  Public  Expenditure  and  Financial  Accountability 
(PEFA) assessment.15

Companies  law  reform.  The  previous  Companies  Act  was  based  on  the  1948  United 
Kingdom Act. It primarily supported large companies and paid little attention to the needs of the 
smaller  companies  comprising  the  majority  of  firms  operating  in  the  economy.  The  new 
Companies Act supports a simpler approach that includes a number of innovations, such as the 
introduction  of  single-shareholder  companies  and  community  companies.  The  innovative 
community companies—a special type of company designed for use by kin groups—enable the 
use of community assets in a way that benefits all members of the community. Such structures 
also improve women’s access to credit and encourage their participation in economic activity by 
making  it  easier  for  them  to  form  new  companies.  The  new  act  provides  a  modern  and 
appropriate codified statement of directors’ duties and removes the compulsory requirement for 
a company secretary. The act has also eliminated unnecessary discretion and removed many of 
the onerous and unnecessary reporting obligations under the previous act. The act needs to be 
supported by a new registry to provide greater certainty around transactions as well as greater 
efficiency. The new Companies Act 2009 is complemented by the Companies (Insolvency and 
Receiverships) Act 2009.

E. 

Responding to Lessons 

An  ADB-funded  public  sector  reform  program  was  initiated  in  August  1998.37  The 
83. 
program aimed at supporting policy reform measures in four main areas: (i) macroeconomic and 
fiscal reforms; (ii) public sector management, including public sector reform, reorientation of the 
public  sector,  and  movement  toward  performance-based  management;  (iii)  SOE  reform, 
including  to  establish  regulatory  frameworks,  corporatization,  and  privatization;  and  (iv) 
strengthening  governance  institutions  to  improve  accountability  and  transparency.  An  early 
review of the program concluded that “(p)rogress has been made in difficult circumstances and 
against  considerable  resistance  from  opponents  of  reform.”38  However,  the  civil  unrest  that 
erupted in mid-1999 ultimately resulted in a new government taking over in mid-2000. The new 
administration  did  not  support  the  program  objectives  and  the  program  ended  prematurely. 
Design of the ERSP has incorporated the lessons from this experience, as well as from ADB’s 
program lending elsewhere in the Pacific and in Asia.39  

84. 
Country ownership is pursued by anchoring the ERSP, MTDS 2008–2010, and the 2009 
and  2010  budgets  to  the  government’s  policy  matrix  while  aligning  actions  with  that  matrix. 
There  is  broadly  based  awareness  of  the  need  for  action,  both  in  response  to  the  global 
economic  crisis  and  to  address  the  need  to  diversify  away  from  logging  and  foreign  aid.  The 
ERSP builds on this awareness.  

85. 
The cluster approach is adopted to provide the extra time and flexibility needed to build a 
demand-driven  program.  Notably,  the  finalization  of  subprogram  2  after  the  2010  general 
election will provide flexibility to align the policy actions with the agenda of any new government. 
This will also facilitate reassessing the political commitment to the ERSP, which is considered 
critical given the long-term nature of the policy actions pursued and ADB’s experience with the 
1998 program loan.40 The cluster approach responds to the lesson that program lending has not 
always been firmly based on an assessment of achievable rates of change and that it has been 
too inflexible where rigidity has contributed to program delays. This approach is a key response 
to the need to innovate in weakly performing countries such as Solomon Islands. 

86. 
Because the creation of new structures and processes can erode country ownership, the 
use of existing institutional structures and enhancing existing systems and processes have been 
emphasized. ADB’s participation in the CEWG process is a key enhancement that will be critical 
to sustaining results from the program.

V. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits and Impacts 

111.  Economic. The program will help address the impact of the global economic crisis that 
has  brought  forward  an  adjustment  expected  as  natural  forests  approach  exhaustion.  The 
government  needs  to  counter  these  developments  by  improving  economic  and  fiscal 
management. The program provides the fiscal resources to a collaborative development partner 
effort to assist Solomon Islands make the adjustment to the new economic environment. 

112.  Social.  The  program  will  help  the  government  limit  any  short-run  increase  in  poverty 
incidence arising from the economic slowdown. This is primarily to be assured by providing the 
financial resources needed for the government to protect funding for basic transport, education, 
and  health  expenditures,  and  thereby  helping  ensure  the  delivery  of  essential  services  to  the 
vulnerable.  No  negative  social  impacts  are  expected.  The  program  will  not  affect  indigenous 
peoples. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 10. 

113.  Environmental.  No  adverse  environmental  impacts  are  anticipated  from  this  program. 
No  environmental  assessment  is  necessary  for  the  program  to  be  implemented.  An 
environmental analysis is in Supplementary Appendix B.

B. 

Risks 

115.  Key risks are that (i) political instability weakens fiscal discipline and policy commitment, 
particularly  in  the  lead-up  to  the  2010  election;48  (ii)  there  will  be  insufficient  capacity  in 
government to implement the program; (iii) the revenue position of the government deteriorates 
and impedes service delivery; and (iv) excessive growth in expenditure will crowd out essential 
expenditure,  making  it  difficult  to  achieve  and  capitalize  on  the  policy  actions  of  the  program 
(e.g.,  because  of  a  large  increase  in  entitlements  for  members  of  Parliament  and/or  a  large 
public sector wage increase). 

116.  Program  design  elements  mitigate  these  risks.  The  first  risk  is  to  be  minimized  by 
operating  the  program  over  two  parliamentary  terms.  This  will  enable  the  government’s 
commitment to be reevaluated after the 2010 election as part of the subprogram 2 formulation, 
and, as necessary, for the ERSP to be tailored  to new circumstances. A communications and 
engagement strategy is also incorporated into the ERSP in an effort to encourage broad-based 
community and political support for the program’s policy actions.  

117.  TA  will  be  provided  on  a  selective  basis  to  supplement  the  expertise  needed  to 
implement key policy actions. It is nonetheless recognized that although there is commitment to 
continuing implementation of the policy agenda, technical and managerial resources are in short 
supply. There is thus a risk that insufficient skilled staff will be retained or recruited by the line 
ministries and public enterprises to ensure the sustainability of policy actions.  

118.  The risk of shortcomings on the fiscal side will be lessened through an explicit focus in 
the ERSP on fiscal discipline. TA on economic and fiscal management will also be available to 
help improve budget formulation and implementation.  

119. 
Importantly,  the  ERSP  also  relies  on  (i)  an  improvement  in  the  global  economy;  (ii)  a 
positive response by the private sector to improved economic conditions; (iii) a commitment of 
government agencies to improve performance; (iv) the provision of complementary financial and 
technical  resources  by  development  partners;  and  (v)  the  continued  operation  of  key 
coordinating mechanisms, notably the 4Ms and the CEWG. 

120.  Overall, the potential benefits from reducing the impact of the global economic crisis and 
providing  improved  basic  services  with  supporting  structural  and  governance  initiatives  are 
considered to outweigh the risks. Indeed, the cost of inaction could be high, particularly if social 
tensions  are  increased  by  weak  economic  conditions  and  problems  in  the  delivery  of  basic 
services by the public sector.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

The well-being of the vast majority of the population has improved little in the years since 
1. 
political  independence  in  1978,  despite  the  rapid  depletion  of  a  major  resource:  the  natural 
forest.1 Real per capita gross domestic product (GDP) has changed little, as the high population 
growth rate (2.9% per annum during 1980–2009) almost kept pace with the moderate long-run 
rate  of  economic  growth  (3.4%  per  annum  during  1980–2009).  This  has  left  the  Solomon 
Islands population of over 500,000 with the second-lowest average income in the region. 
 
2. 
Formal sector job creation has not kept pace with the increase in the labor supply, and 
the open unemployment rate rose to 11% in 1999. It is reported that in recent years only one in 
every six school-leavers has found paid employment and that the youth unemployment rate is 
45%. Many of those who have not found formal sector jobs have become underemployed in the 
subsistence sector, where women’s work has so far managed to feed the growing population. 
However,  population  pressure  on  arable  land  has  become  evident  in  some  areas:  in  Malaita, 
“steep slopes or hilly non-arable land are increasingly being cultivated.”2 
 
3. 
Like other small island states, Solomon Islands is disadvantaged by (i) remoteness from 
major  world  markets,  (ii)  the  difficulty  of  achieving  adequate  economies  of  scale  in  the 
production  of  goods  and  provision  of  public  services,  and  (iii)  risks  due  to  a  narrow  economic 
base  and  vulnerability  to  natural  disasters.  Natural  shocks  have  included  cyclones  Namu  in 
1986 and Nina in 1993, as well as a tsunami in April 2007. Economic shocks have ranged from 
commodity  price  declines  to  the  1997  Asian  financial  crisis  and,  more  recently,  rising  oil  and 
food prices and the global economic crisis. 
 
4. 
As  noted  by  the  governor  of  the  Central  Bank  of  Solomon  Islands,  however,  the  poor 
post-independence  development  performance  largely  is  attributable  to  “self-inflicted  injuries  or 
things  which  the  country  could  have  avoided  by  prompt  action.”3  These  have  included 
succumbing  to  the  danger  of  dominant  foreign  investors  exercising  undue  political  influence, 
thereby undermining domestic governance and introducing corruption.4 
 
5. 
The  legislative  and  executive  arms  of  government  have  failed  in  several  respects. 
Notably,  public  sector  management  (revenue  administration,  public  expenditure  management 
and  public  administration,  including  policy  development  and  coordination)  has  been  weak.  A 
lack of fiscal discipline during a period of export-led growth in the late 1980s and into the 1990s 
drove  the  economy  into  crisis  by  1995,  leaving  it  with  an  unsustainable  public  debt  burden. 
Simultaneously,  under-taxation  and  under-invoicing  of  log  exports  caused  a  loss  of  revenue 
during 1990–1997 that was more than double the cumulative recurrent budget deficit during this 
period. The failure to capture a reasonable domestic share of the resource rent from logging the 
natural forest has continued into the 21st century.

Economic Prospects 

9. 
Economic growth prospects rest on developments in mining, agriculture, fishing, and, to 
a lesser extent, tourism. A large gold mine closed during the civil unrest is near to reopening, 
and there is potential to develop large nickel deposits. While mining projects would boost GDP, 
the sector would employ few people and there would be long lags before the projects boosted 
government revenue. The best prospects for job creations and growth in government revenue 
lie  in  large-scale  palm  oil  developments,  in  fishing  (there  is  already  one  large  cannery),  in 
marine products, and in the smallholder tree crops of cocoa and copra. The supply of fruit and 
vegetables to the urban centers as a substitute for imports also offers good prospects, as does 
the fledgling tourism industry. 
 
10.

various  scenarios  and  assumptions.  The  studies  have  identified  the  potential  for  economic 
growth after logging, albeit at only low to moderate rates that would see at best slow growth in 
real GDP per capita. The studies have also highlighted the necessity of concerted government 
action to realize the potential growth and the downside risk of inaction.

To  achieve  sustained,  diversified,  and  more  socially  inclusive  economic  growth,  the 
20.

21.

Institutional Setting 

A. 
 
After  just  30  years  of  political  independence,  nationhood  remains  a  fragile  concept.1 
1. 
Solomon Islands has a Westminster government, but parliamentarians enter Parliament with a 
different  view  of  parliament  and  government  compared  with  their  counterparts  in  similar,  well 
functioning  institutions  overseas.  Their  local  political  experience  is  one  in  which  leadership  is 
often  a  function  of  wealth  and  the  ability  to  use  that  wealth  to  reinforce  or  raise  one’s  local 
political  standing  through  the  wantok  system  of  kinship  and  allegiance.2  In  Parliament,  it  is  to 
that support base that the successful candidate’s focus is often confined and to the detriment of 
more  broadly  representing  a  constituency  or  working  toward  the  good  of  the  nation.  The 
development  and  entrenchment  of  a  sense  of  nationhood  in  the  realm  of  Solomon  Islands 
politics  is  therefore  seen  as  an  important  key  to  sustainable  improvement  in  government 
performance. 
 
The first-past-the-post electoral system operates in small electorates where there is no 
2. 
restriction on the number of candidates. A candidate can gain election with a minority of votes 
based  predominantly  on  kin-based  support.  The  electoral  system  thus  produces  a  “highly 
unstable  mixture  of  weak  parties  and  independent  parliamentarians,  who  then  negotiate  the 
creation of coalition governments that divide the political spoils between them”.3 To address this 
inherent instability, a Political Parties Integrity Bill has been prepared that aims to give a newly 
elected  government  some  breathing  space  from  politicians  who,  having  initially  professed 
support for a leader, might choose to cross the floor.

10. 
The alignment of public expenditure with national development priorities, as outlined in 
the  government’s  medium  term  development  strategy,  is  being  strengthened  by  strategic 
allocation  of  public  resources  through  the  annual  recurrent  and  development  budgets.  The 
government  appropriates  on  an  annual  cash  basis  to  each  ministry.  The  appropriation  is  also 
specified in a detailed breakdown of inputs for two major categories of recurrent expenditure: (i) 
payroll, and (ii) other charges for each cost center within a ministry. The basis for appropriation 
is under review. The budget is formulated in consultation with spending ministries. From 2007, 
interdepartmental  consultation  has  started  an  early  stage  in  the  budget  preparation  process.

22.  Solomon  Islands  lacks  formal  social  safety  nets.  Most  Solomon  Islanders  rely  on  their 
ability to earn a subsistence living and some additional cash income from their land and marine 
resources as an informal social safety net. Strong communities and the wantok system are also 
an  important  informal  safeguard.  Under  the  wantok  system,  those  that  speak  the  same 
language (or share “one talk”) traditionally look out for one another. The  wantok system could 
be  seen  as an  unwritten  social  contract  between  those  speaking  the  same  language  to  assist 
each other in times of need. The informal social safety nets are still strong, and they are critical 
to limiting the most extreme forms of poverty in the Solomon Islands. But the relevance of the 
traditional sources of support is declining as families move to urban areas and away from their 
land and as communities monetize. They are also better suited to situations where only some 
members of the community bear extra stress, rather than to the situation of generalized stress 
ensuing from the extremely high inflation of 2008 that was triggered by high commodity prices 
and  now  the  economic  slowdown.  To  date,  there  has  been  limited  provision  of  formal  social 
safety nets. More effort is warranted to help lessen the strain now borne by the vulnerable.

Overview of Gender Situation 

 
A. 
 
1. 
The government is committed to promoting gender equity in national as well as regional 
and international development policy frameworks. However, Solomon Islands ranks very low, by 
regional  comparison,  in  both  gender  development  and  gender  empowerment  indices.  Women 
have less access to and control of key political, economic, and knowledge resources than men. 
Currently,  there  is  no  female  member  in  the  national  parliament.  There  is  a  strong  traditional 
obligation system that functions as a basic safety net but that also restricts individual control of 
land and exacerbates women’s lack of access to economic resources. 
 
2. 
Gender  inequity  is  salient  in  the  areas  of  education  and  health.  Females  have  less 
access than males to education, especially at higher levels of schooling, which results in lower 
literacy  rates  among  adult  women.  Women’s  access  to  health  and  family  planning  services 
remains poor particularly in rural areas, while the fertility rate is one of the highest in the Pacific. 
Lack of investments into women’s education and health undermines their productive capacities 
for income-generating activities, as well as the health and nutritional status of their children. The 
current economic crisis is likely to worsen these situations unless the government maintains and 
improves the provision of social services essential for girls and women.  
 
3. 
Poverty  disproportionately  affects  women  and  children.  Additional  factors  such  as 
endemic  malaria  and  natural  disasters  exacerbate  poverty  and  create  increased  burdens  for 
women  as  caregivers,  subsistence  farmers,  and  community  members.  Gaps  in  such  basic 
infrastructure  services  as  roads,  clean  water,  and  sanitation  further  limit  women’s  time  and 
opportunity, since women bear the primary responsibility for household management and child 
care. Gender-based violence is prevalent, and increased economic hardship places women and 
girls at greater risk both in and outside the family.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
The Solomon Islands Medium Term Development Strategy (MTDS), 2008–2010 focuses on six priorities: (i) reconciliation 
and rehabilitation, (ii) national security and foreign relations, (iii) infrastructure development, (iv) the social services sector, 
(v) the economic and productive sectors, and (vi) civic affairs. The overarching priority of the current MTDS is post-conflict 
reconciliation.  The  MTDS  also  accords  a  high  priority  for  infrastructure  development  and  private  sector-led  growth.  The 
government  has  pronounced  its  intentions  to  align  the  budget  formulation  and  implementation  process  to  the  MTDS 
priorities, especially in terms of delivering essential services and policy reform.  
 
The ADB Solomon Islands interim country partnership strategy, 2009–2011 is aligned with the MTDS.a It seeks to reduce 
poverty  by  promoting  equitable  private  sector-led  economic  growth  through  improved  transportation  infrastructure  and 
services and a stronger business enabling environment. Capacity development and the promotion of good governance are 
guiding priorities. 
 
The Economic Recovery Support Program (ERSP) is anchored in the MTDS. It will provide early, prudent action to help 
reduce  the  economic  and  fiscal  imbalances  aggravated  by  the  global  economic  crisis.  This  will  in  turn  help  avoid  the 
reemergence  of  potentially  destabilizing  social  tensions.  The  ERSP  contains  macroeconomic-  and  microeconomic-level 
measures  that  will  improve  the  environment  for  the  private  sector,  thereby  contributing  to  achievement  of  the  country 
partnership strategy. It also contains specific measures to help protect the vulnerable. 

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification:   General intervention 
1. Key Issues  
The nature of poverty in the Solomon Islands, as in other Pacific developing member countries, relates more to a lack of 
access  to  quality  essential  services  (such  as  water  and  sanitation  or  health  and  education  facilities)  and  lack  of  income 
earning opportunities than to widespread hunger or destitution. In urban areas, there is better access to cash income but 
poorer  access  to  own-produced  food  and  higher  cash  requirements  for  food  and  nonfood  expenditures.  In  rural  areas, 
where  the  majority  of  the  country’s  population  is  located  and  many  households  are  engaged  in  subsistence  agriculture, 
there is greater access to own-produced food and a lesser need for nonfood expenditure, but there are larger gaps here in 
access to essential services. 
 
The years of conflict that started in 1999 led to collapse of the country’s economy and disruption to the delivery of many 
basic  services,  thus  resulting  in  a  significant  increase  in  poverty.  Although  progress  has  been  made  in  restoring  many 
basic  services  with  substantial  external  assistance,  levels  of  coverage  and  quality  are  generally  inadequate  outside  of 
urban areas. 
 
There  is  almost  no  explicit  targeted  support  to  the  vulnerable,  as  the  country  lacks  a  formal  social  safety  net  system. 
Those  living  outside  the  formal  economy  rely  on  the  ability  to  earn  a  subsistence  living  and  perhaps  some  additional 
income  from  their  land  and  marine  resources.  The  wantok  system  is  also  an  important  safeguard.  Under  the  wantok 
system, those who speak the same language (thus sharing “one talk”) traditionally look out for one another. The wantok 
system could be seen as an unwritten social contract between those that speak the same language to assist each other in 
times of need, and land is collectively owned by the wantok. While still strong, the relevance of these traditional sources of 
support is declining as families move to urban areas and away from their land, and as communities monetize. They are 
better  suited  to  situations  where  only  some  members  of  the  community  bear  extra  stress,  rather  than  to  the  situation  of 
generalized stress arising from earlier high inflation and now the economic slowdown. 
 
2. Design Features  
Support for the vulnerable is a feature of the program, in recognition of the extra hardship imposed by the global economic 
crisis  and  the  preceding  episode  of  high  international  commodity  prices.  Essential  public  services  used  by  the  most 
vulnerable (i.e., basic transport, health, and education services) have been identified, and ADB grant resources will help 
maintain spending over 2010 and 2011 on the goods and services used in their delivery. 
 
In addition, a linked project, Supporting and Building Resilience of the Vulnerable, is proposed for financing from the Japan

C.  Gender and Development 

1.  Key Issues.  
Women in Solomon Islands suffer disproportionately from poor access to essential social services and limited control over 
economic resources. Gender disparities are significant in education and health, and the situations can further deteriorate 
with increases in economic hardship. There is a very low progression rate from primary to secondary education, with only 
a 27% secondary enrollment rate for girls and a girl:boy ratio of 0.87. As cultural biases favor the education of boys over 
girls,  girls  are  more  often  pulled  out  of  school  for  economic  reasons,  household  chores,  and  farm  labor.  While  fertility 
remains one of the highest in the Pacific region (4.4 live births per woman), women’s access to health and family planning 
services is poor, and particularly so in rural areas. This results in high maternal mortality rate (220 per 100,000 live births). 
Lack of adequate access to reproductive care also leads to poor nutritional and health status of children. With poor access 
to basic infrastructure services in rural areas—such as roads, safe water, and improved sanitation facilities—women bear 
a  disproportionate  burden  in  managing  households.  This  means  women  have  little  time  and  opportunity  for  other 
productive and income-generating activities. In addition, women have limited access to formal or informal credit due to the
